required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.official_title: Safety and Efficacy of Booster Doses of BNT162b2 Vaccine in Immunocompromised Patients With a Cancer Diagnosis

brief_summary.textblock: The goal of this study is to assess the safety and effectiveness of a COVID vaccine booster in patients with cancer who have not developed an antibody after the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) Emergency Use Authorized COVID vaccination series

primary_outcome.measure: Rates of seroconversion for SARS-CoV-2 spike antibody

intervention.description: administer an additional dose of the BNT162b2 mRNA vaccine to patients with cancer who have a negative SARS-CoV-2 Spike IgG at least 14 days after 2 doses of the mRNA vaccines (BNT162b2/mRNA-1273) or 28 days after the adenoviral based Ad26CoV2.S vaccine.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Above the age of 18
- Known diagnosis of any malignancy- either active or completed therapy
- Underwent an in-person encounter at a study facility during the study period
- Have a negative SARS-CoV-2 spike IgG at least 14 days after the second dose of the mRNA-based vaccines (Moderna or Pfizer/BioNTech) or 28 days after a single dose of the adenovirus-based Johnson & Johnson vaccine.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Patients who have had a serious adverse reaction to any prior COVID-19 vaccines resulting in emergency room visit or hospitalization, had events related to myocarditis, thrombosis and thrombocytopenia syndrome or anaphylaxis to any prior dose of the COVID-19 vaccines.
- Patients who have had a documented COVID-19 infection in the 90 days prior to starting the study
